abstract.para: This document introduces the key concepts of Information Sharing Planning, gives a tour of the Channels ISP web application, defines the ISP Method, and briefly compares Information Sharing Planning with Business Process Management.

section.title: Why plan information sharing
section.para: Organizations operate in an increasingly inter-connected and inter-dependent world. Systemic risks are growing. Organizations must network to compete in a global marketplace. They can no longer respond to major crisis nor can they seize global business opportunities on their own. Success now largely depends on the timely and targeted sharing of information within and between organizations.
During a crisis, information will not spontaneously flow as needed. Maintaining contact lists is not enough; organizations must plan ahead and create actionable information sharing procedures.
Information Sharing Planning provides a framework and method for designing and improving the information sharing procedures required to successfully manage systemic risks and seize opportunities.

section.title: Benefits and deliverables

para.emphasis: Information Sharing Planning captures, analyzes and deploys knowledge of how organizations need to share information to mitigate systemic risks and seize opportunities from anticipated events.

section.para: Information Sharing Planning (ISP) produces information sharing procedures for event preparedness, response and recovery. Information Sharing Plans capture commitments to share the information required for organizations to fulfill their missions.
ISP uncovers:

listitem.para: who needs what information, and why and when,
who has or can produce needed information, and how and when,
what information should flow, and when and how,
the consequences of not sharing according to Plan.

section.para: The deliverables of ISP are:

listitem.para: documented information sharing procedures
information flow analytics and visualizations,
detected information sharing gaps, bottlenecks and single points of failure.

section.para:
It is important understand that an Information Sharing Plan is not an action plan. Its objective is not to dictate a sequence of actions.
However, task sequencing is not entirely absent from ISP. A task may require information produced by another task that would then necessarily precede it. These sequencing constraints do not typically apply to all tasks and they certainly do not dictate a unique ordering for all tasks. In any case, attempting to define an action plan for organizations that don't have a central authority is more often than not an exercise in futility. What really matters here is capturing what needs to be done, what information is required and produced, and how and when it should or should not be shared. Information sharing planning concerns itself exclusively with capturing information sharing requirements for necessary tasks to be carried out successfully.

section.title: What is an Information Sharing Plan?
In a nutshell
section.para: An Information Sharing Plan captures the information sharing procedures (tasks and information sharing) that people and systems (agents) in roles of responsibility are expected to apply, within their jurisdictions, in order to fulfill the missions of their organizations before, during and/or after events of significance.

Tasks manage risks, achieve gains and/or produce information needed by other tasks. Information sharing flows connect tasks that produce information with tasks that consume it. Shared information is communicated over transmission media or face to face. Sharing can be subject to policies.

A task specifies, in more or less generic terms, which agents should be assigned to it, individually or as teams. Information sharing procedures are generated by matching agents within the scope of the Plan to the tasks. Agents are bound by information sharing commitments whenever they are assigned to tasks that are connected by flows to other tasks. These agents commit to share the information they produce with all agents who execute the connected-to tasks that consume it. An implied but important constraint is that information can only be used to execute tasks for which it is explicitly shared.

section.title: Plan segments
section.para: Information sharing plans typically deal with more than one phase of more that one anticipated event, and they can involve a large number of organizations. Because plans can become quite large, planners break them into smaller, more manageable units of planning called segments.

An information sharing segment covers only one phase of one event and addresses some of the related organizational goals. A segment will typically focus on just a few goals. Segments usually depend on other segments. Two segments are co-dependent when information produced by a task in one segment is consumed by a task in the other, or when a task in one segment initiates the event phase covered by the other segment.

section.title: Tasks and flows
section.para: A task describes an action carried out at some location and for some purpose by one or more agents. Agents act to fulfill the responsibilities of roles bestowed on them by organizations. The agents expected to carry out a task can be identified by any combination of name, role, jurisdiction and organization. The executor of a task may be identified only partially (for example, by role and organization only) so that more than one person or system will match the profile and get assigned to the task. According to a tasks' definition, those assigned to the task are expected to carry it out either as a team or on their own.
Tasks are considered useful if they:

listitem.para: directly achieve risk mitigation or gains,
initiate or terminate (phases of) events,
or produce information needed by other useful tasks.

section.para: Tasks can be triggered or terminated by:

listitem.para: awareness of events,
notifications they receive,
requests for information they receive.

section.para: Information flows link tasks that produce information to tasks that consume it. A flow is characterized by:

listitem.para: the information communicated (down to its elements, each with optional secrecy classifications and optional sourcing and handling instructions),
the intent of the flow (alarm, announcement, command, feedback or report)
the mode of communication (request vs notification, unicast vs multicast vs broadcast),
restrictions, if any, based on shared organization membership or location of the source and/or target of the flow,
a list of preferred transmission media (phone, face-to-face etc.),
the impacts, if any, the communication may have (it might trigger or terminate a task),
instructions on how to carryout the task,
policies that mandate or prohibit sharing.

section.title: Entities
section.para: Plans, segments, tasks, information needs, capabilities and sharing flows are defined in terms of agents, places, roles, organizations, events, transmission media and phases of events. These are called entities. An ISP entity can be unambiguously referenced by name in the specifications of tasks and flows, and in the profiles of other entities.

There are actual entities and types of entities. Actual entities (“Jane Smith”, “ACME Inc.”, “Morristown, Morris County, NJ, USA” etc.) are categorized by types of entities (“Senior executive”, “Corporation”, “City” etc.). Entity types can refine other entity types (a “Senior executive” is an “Executive”).

An agent is either a person or an information processing system (system for short). A system is capable of sending notifications, answering queries, receiving notifications or sending queries. An agent has contact information. An agent's clearance is a list of secrecy classifications. A secrecy classification has a name (“NATO”) and an ordered list of secrecy levels (“Restricted”, “Confidential”, “Secret”, “Focal Top Secret”, “Cosmic Top Secret”). An agent type can be thought of as a qualification that can be shared by different agents (e.g. "adult" or "registered driver"). An agent type is not to be confused with a role. An agent can be flagged as a system (non-human). When a group of agents are indistinguisable from a planning perspective (for example, call center operators), they can be profiled as a single archetype agent.

An organization is a group of agents organized to accomplish a mission. An organization assigns roles of responsibility to the persons and systems that act on its behalf. An organization has contact information and may contain other organizations. An organization may have information sharing agreements with other organizations to formalize the sharing commitments its members have with members of other organizations.
A role is a set of powers and responsibilities bestowed by an organization to an agent acting on behalf of the organization. A role assignment may be restricted to a jurisdiction (a place).

A place is either a geographical area (some city, county, state, country, natural preserve etc.) or a known location (some train station, building etc.). A place can be contained in another (for example, a building can be in a campus). An event and an event type can both be scoped to a place.
A phase names a time period relative to an event. A phase of an event is either set to before, during or after the event. Typical phases are “Preparing”, “Responding” and “Recovering”.

A transmission medium is a means by which agents transmit information to one another. A medium is either unicast (transmits to a single, known agent), multicast (transmits to multiple, known agents) or broadcast (little to no control over who receives the transmission). Transmission media may or may not be technology-based. “Telephone”, “Email”, “Instant Messaging” are examples of unicast communication media, and so is “Face-to-face”. “Notification system” and “Meeting” are both multicast media. “Television”, “Radio” and “PA System” are examples of broadcast media. A transmission medium can delegate transmissions to other media (for example, VoIP can interface with Telephones). The security of a medium is expressed in terms of secrecy classifications.

section.title: Issues
section.para: ISP identifies many different kinds of issues (70 and counting) about tasks, information flows, entities and entire segments and plans. There are issues of validity (definition errors), completeness (something obvioudly missing from the Plan) and robustness (something that makes the Plan failure-prone). An issue has a description, a list of suggested remediations, and a severity level (minor, major, severe, extreme). The severity is either a constant or it is calculated from the potential cascade of task failures attributable to the issue.

chapter.title: The ISP Method
chapter.para: Information sharing planners (Planners) apply the ISP Method to build information sharing plans (Plans) from which robust information sharing procedures (Procedures) can be generated. These Procedures enable participating organizations to fulfill their missions before, during and/or after one or more events of significance.

The ISP Method defines:
the conceptual building blocks of a Plan,
the activities by which a Plan is built, with prerequisites, steps and outcomes,
strategies for moving a Plan to completion,
and issues that may keep a Plan from being valid, complete and robust
The ISP Method

section.title: ISP Method and ISP Process
section.para: The ISP Method is part of the ISP Process. The ISP Process adds to the ISP Method Best Practices for the successful promotion, definition, initiation and execution of information sharing planning projects.

ISP Method activities (Activities) should not be confused with Best Practices. For example, a Best Practice might help planners decide what the scope a Plan should be, whereas an Activity would prescribe how to capture the scope of a Plan (once decided upon) and indicate which Activities are triggered by changes to the scope.

section.title: From Plans to Procedures
section.para: A Plan consists of tasks that achieve organizational goals during various phases of anticipated events. These tasks consume information that may be produced by other tasks and then shared by the agents who execute them.

Known agents from participating organizations are assigned (or not) to tasks based on whether the profile of each agent matches the specifications of who is meant to execute a given task. The profile of an agent is defined in terms of the agent’s qualifications, the roles the agent plays in organizations, and the agent’s jurisdictions.

When a flow connects an information-producing task (source task) with an information-consuming task (target task), then all agents assigned to the source task commit to sharing information with the agents assigned to the target task. The information is strictly to be used for the execution of the target task.
The sum of all task assignments and sharing commitments for a given agent is this agent’s Procedures.

section.title: Building a Plan
section.para: A Plan is built by information sharing planners (Planners) who carry out Activities defined in the ISP Method in order to move the Plan toward completion.

section.title: Activities
section.para: Activities either alter the scope of a Plan, bring the Plan closer to completion, or improve the quality and value of the Procedures generated from it.

Activities are organized into these four groups:
Scoping (a Plan),
Specifying (tasks and information flows from which Procedures are derived),
Profiling (referenced events, organizations, roles and other entities), and
Improving (making changes to a plan to make it more manageable or more valuable)
Scoping a plan (these Activities initiate planning but can be iterated on throughout):
defining (incident) events and phases
listing participating organizations and members
adding a segment to the plan
listing organization goals per event phase
Specifying information sharing procedures:

listitem.para: specifying a task with its agents, needs, capabilities, effects...
connecting tasks with sharing flows defined in terms of info shared, channels, timing, impacts...

section.para: Profiling referenced entities:

listitem.para: profiling events, phases, organizations, roles, places, media, agents
as actual or types of entities (as applicable)

section.para: Improving a plan (reorganizing/restructuring a plan to increase its manageability or applicability, or making changes with global impacts on the generated Procedures):

listitem.para: moving tasks between segments
generalizing a task specification
changing an entity’s type tags

section.para: There is no fixed, prescribed order to the execution of Activities. Scope can be modified at any time while a Plan is being built. Tasks and information flows can also be specified at any time. Entities (events, roles, organizations, agents, phases, places, transmission media etc.) can be profiled as soon they are mentioned by name in the specifications of tasks and information flows, the profiles of other entities, or in the definition of the Plan’s scope. A Plan should be improved early and often in order to keep it as manageable and as valuable as possible.

section.title: Issues
section.para: The ISP Method defines a relatively large number of issues that relate to a Plan’s

listitem.para: validity (something is incorrectly specified or defined),
completeness (something is apparently missing), or
robustness (something makes the Plan failure-prone).

section.para: An issue can be about the Plan as a whole or about an element of the Plan (a task specification, role profile, segment definition etc.).

An issue has a severity of low, medium, high, very high or extreme. The severity of an issue is either constant or computed by determining the severity of a potential cascade of failures caused by the issue.
An issue comes with one or more alternate options for remediation. Some issues are “best guesses” and can be waived by Planners.
All defined issues can be automatically detected by software. Planners can report other, ad hoc issues; these will typically be domain-specific issues.

section.title: Moving to completion
section.para: When is a plan complete? Because one could always increase the scope of a Plan, a more useful question would be: Given its current scope, is there something clearly missing from a Plan? If the answer is no, then the Plan can be considered “complete”.

Nothing is clearly missing from a Plan if:
Each phase of each event in scope is addressed by at least one segment of the Plan (see definition of segment).
Each segment has at least one defined goal.
Each goal listed in a segment is achieved by at least one task within that segment.
All participating organizations and agents within scope are assigned tasks.
All information sharing flows imply sharing commitments by known agents.
All outstanding issues are waived.
The scope of a plan can be changed even after it is deemed complete. Plan tasks, flows and entities that do not contribute to completing a Plan are considered redundant. Redundant tasks, flows or entities should be removed from a Plan. If the scope of a Plan is reduced, some elements of a plan may become redundant.
There are three distinct strategies for driving a Plan to completion:

listitem.para: goals-driven,
effect-driven and
issue-driven.

section.para: Planners will usually use of all three strategies at once.

section.title: Goal-driven strategy
section.para: Planners look at each organizational goal attached to a phase of an anticipated event, specify tasks that achieve it, and the information needs of each of these tasks. They then specify tasks that produce the needed information and connect the tasks with sharing flows. This process continues until all goals are addressed by tasks and all task information needs are satisfied.

Tasks and flows thus specified and, consequently, the Procedures generated from them are necessarily within the scope of the Plan, since they all contribute directly or indirectly to addressing identified goals.

section.title: Effect-driven strategy
section.para: Planners start with the onset of an event phase, specify tasks that are directly triggered by it. They then specify the information produced by the tasks. and then the tasks that would be triggered or terminated by sharing this information. Planners connect the tasks with sharing flows as appropriate. This process continues until no task gets triggered or terminated by information produced by specified tasks.

Some tasks and flows specified using this strategy (and thus Procedures generated from them) might not all belong within the scope of the Plan since they do not necessarily contribute directly or indirectly to addressing identified goals.

section.title: Issue-driven strategy
section.para: Planners scan the list of detected issues. Issues can be about validity (incorrectly defined plan elements), completeness (plan elements obviously missing) and robustness (Procedures are resilient to failures). They then select an issue to be addressed and 1- waive the issue (if applicable and if the issue is a false negative), or 2- decide on applying a remediation Activity (possibly chosen from recommendations provided with the issue). The process is repeated until all outstanding issues are waived.

A Plan with no outstanding, “unwaived” issues could be considered valid, complete and robust, assuming that all possible material issues were indeed detected (an assumption that is impossible to verify).

section.title: Activities
section.para: An ISP Method Activity is carried out by a Planner to achieve an outcome that (ideally) brings a plan closer to completion. An Activity is composed of a number of steps, many or all optional, often carried out in no specific order. Most Activities can be undone (for example, a specified task can be later removed). When they exist, the prerequisites for an Activity are usually few and commonsensical; for example, a task in a segment can not be specified unless the segment is already defined.

The outcomes of an Activity can be completely or partially undone at any time. This is accomplished by removing a task specification, deleting a Plan segment, removing a member from an organization, reverting to a prior specification or definition etc.). Such “reverse Activities” are not listed but are usually implied.
Prior to applying any activtiy, it is assumed that:

listitem.para: a plan has been created and given a unique identifier (the identifier is not the name of the plan; it is universally unique and can not be changed)
users have been authorized as planners
a default segment is created for a default phase of a default incident event

section.para: Activities fall under scoping a plan, specifying information sharing procedures, profiling entities, or improving a plan.

section.title: Scoping a plan
section.para: The Scoping Activities are:

listitem.para: Localize the Plan
Name an anticipated event
Name a planned phase
Name a participating organization
Identify a participant
Add a segment
Set an organizational goal

section.title: Localize the Plan
section.para: Outcomes
Place types can now be defined relative to the plan’s reference location.
Prerequisites
The Plan was created.
Steps

listitem.para: Optionally name the reference location of the plan (an actual or type of place)

section.title: Name an anticipated event
section.para: Outcomes
An additional event must be planned for.
Prerequisites
The Plan was created.
Steps

listitem.para: Name the event
Indicate whether the event is an incident (there must be at least one incident per plan)

section.title: Name a planned phase
section.para: Outcomes
An additional phase must be planned for each event in scope.
Prerequisites
The Plan was created.
Steps

listitem.para: Name the phase
Identify whether it is pre-, co- or post-event

section.title: Name a participating organization
section.para: Outcomes
An organization is identified as an expected participant.
Prerequisites
The Plan was created.
Steps

listitem.para: Name the organization
Indicate that its participation is expected
Profile the organization

section.title: Identify a participant
section.para: Outcomes
An agent is identified as an expected participant.
Prerequisites
The organizations the agent is a participating member of are named.
Steps

listitem.para: Name the agent in the job roster of a participating organization
Give the job’s title, and name the role and, optionally, jurisdiction
Profile the role, agent and jurisdiction, if named

section.title: Add a segment
section.para: Outcomes
The plan can now cover another event phase or the tasks and flows that address an organizational goal for an event phase can be moved to the new segment.
Prerequisites
The Plan was created.
Steps

listitem.para: Create the segment, then
Name the segment
Name the event and phase it covers

section.title: Add an organizational goal
section.para: Outcomes
Mitigation of a risk to or capture of a gain by an organization is added to the scope.
Prerequisites
The segment to address the goal is created
Steps

listitem.para: Select risk mitigation or gain capture then, in any order,
Categorize the risk or gain
Set the level of risk or magnitude of the gain
Name the organization at risk or who would benefit
Describe the goal

section.title: Specifying procedures
section.para: The Specifying Activities are:

listitem.para: Specify a task
Specify an information flow
Specify an information need
Specify an information capability
Specify an information sharing

section.title: Specify a task
section.para: Outcomes
A task is added to a segment of the Plan and agents may be assigned to it.
Prerequisites
The containing segment is created.
Steps

listitem.para: Name the task
Categorize it (operations, operations management, operational coordination, direction, audit, analysis, preparing/planning or policy-setting)
A task can be categorized as:
operations (primary activities, the work that directly accomplishes the mission of the organization)
operations management (directly regulating and measuring operations)
inter-operations coordination (avoiding and resolving operational conflicts but without involving higher ups)
direction (what the higher ups do: operational cohesion and optimization, resource allocation, setting performance targets)
audit (verification of operational performance measures by higher ups)
analysis (making sense of the external environment)
planning/preparing (forward looking activities: market research, forward planning, strategy, R&D)
policy-setting (the ultimate authority: mission definition and evolution, ethos, balancing the demands of now vs future).
Name the location of its execution
Name the actual or type of agent assigned to it
Name the role of the agents assigned
Name the jurisdiction for the role
Name the actual or type of organization the agents represent
Indicate whether assignees execute the task as a team or separately
Named the event the task causes, if any
Describe how long the task usually takes to complete, and whether it recurs and after how long
Indicate whether the task is immediate
Indicate whether successful execution of the task can terminate the phase of the event of the segment it is in
Identify the goals of this segment the task achieves, if any
Enter any instructions for the assignees
Attach/link and name policy an reference documents

section.title: Specify an information need, capability or flow
section.para: Outcomes
An information need, capability or sharing is added to a task.
Prerequisites
The task is added to the segment.
Steps
(All steps are optional and they can be taken in any order)

listitem.para: Name the information
Categorize its intent (alarm, announcement, command, feedback or report)
The intent of a flow can be one of:
report (summary of facts and conjectures: "Here's what we know...")
command (an injunction: "Do this!" "Stop that!")
announcement (declaration, communiqué, advertisement: “I-95 is congested”, “Spinach is safe”)
feedback (thumbs up or down, reward, punishment: "Objectives were met", "Report is incomplete")
alarm (signal of an unexpected change requiring outside assistance: "Distribution point is overwhelmed!", “Levee is breached”)
Name its elements and, if applicable,
identify their secrecy classifications
give sourcing details
give handling instructions
Indicate whether the information would be shared as a notification or as an answer to a request
Whether the information must go to/come from an agent in
the same overall organization
the same organization
the same location
List the alternate transmission channels to be used
Indicate the impact on the task of sending or receiving the information
Give time constraints on sending or receiving the information
Enter instructions
Attach/link and name a policy (mandating, prohibiting, constraining) document, reference document or illustrative media file.

section.title: Specify an information need (extends Specify an information need, capability or flow)
section.para: Outcomes
An information need is added to a task.
Prerequisites
(as in Specify an information need, capability or flow)
Steps
(as in Specify an information need, capability or flow)

listitem.para: the impact of fulfilling the need can be to trigger the task or make a critical contribution to its success
the time constraint is the maximum delay between receiving the information and it becoming available (if notification) or it being requested (if answer to request)

section.title: Specify an information capability (extends Specify an information need, capability or flow)
section.para: Outcomes
An information capability is added to a task.
Prerequisites
(as in Specify an information need, capability or flow)
Steps
(as in Specify an information need, capability or flow) except

listitem.para: the impact of sharing the information produced could be to terminate the task
the time constraint is the maximum delay between producing the information and sharing it (if notification offered) or it being requested and sharing it (if answer to request offered)

section.title: Specify an information sharing (extends Specify an information need, capability or flow)
section.para: Outcomes
Information sharing commitments are specified between a producing task and a consuming task.
Prerequisites
(as in Specify an information need, capability or flow)
Steps
(as in Specify an information need, capability or flow) except

listitem.para: the source or target of the flow is identified (depending on whether the flow is looked at form the perspective of the target or source of the flow)
the impacts on both source and target tasks are given

section.title: Profiling entities
section.para: The Profiling Activities are:

listitem.para: Profile an event type
Profile a phase
Profile a place
Profile an organization
Profile a role
Profile an agent
Profile a transmission medium

section.title: Profile an event type (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes
An entity referenced in the Plan is profiled, which depending on the kind of entity, may alter task assignments and thus information sharing commitments.
Prerequisites
The entity is referenced by name in the Plan either as an actual or type of entity (roles, phases and transmission media can only be types).
Steps
(All steps are optional and they can be taken in any order)

listitem.para: Name or change the name (a name must be unique for the kind of entity)
Give a description (free text)
Tag the entity with the names of entity types of the same kind (e.g. The actual place “Headquarters” is tagged with place type “Building”)
Attach/link reference and policy documents

section.title: Profile a phase (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes
An event referenced in the Plan is profiled.
Prerequisites
(as in Profile an entity)
Steps
(Added to steps in Profile an entity)

listitem.para: Name a place (actual or type) where the event would occur

section.title: Profile a phase (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes
Changing in mid-plan the meaning of a phase (changing it from pre-event to post-event, for example) can profoundly alter the meaning of the entire plan.
Prerequisites
(as in Profile an entity)
Steps
(Optionally added to steps in Profile an entity)

listitem.para: Set the phase as either pre-event, co-event or post-event

section.title: Profile a place (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes
Assignments may change for tasks that specify a jurisdiction, and thus sharing commitments as well.
Prerequisites
(as in Profile an entity)
Steps
(Optionally added to steps in Profile an entity)

listitem.para: Name another actual place this place is within
If an actual place:
Give the street address, postal code, city, county, state and country
If a type of place:
Declare it to be inside either the plan’s locale, the location of an event or a named place (actual or type)
Declare it to contain either the plan’s locale, the location of an event or a named place (actual or type)

section.title: Profile an organization (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes
Assignments may change for tasks that specify an organization, and thus sharing commitments as well.
Prerequisites
(as in Profile an entity)
Steps
(Optionally added to steps in Profile an entity)

listitem.para: Describe the mission
Name an actual parent organization
If an actual organization:
Name the location of the organization (an actual place)
Give contact info for the organization as a whole (as endpoints on transmission media)
Declare that there should be no sharing commitment not covered by a sharing agreement
Declare that a role associated with the organization should be assigned to at least one agent
Define memberships in the organization (aka jobs):
Naming an agent (mandatory)
Giving a job title (mandatory)
Naming a role (mandatory)
Naming a jurisdiction (optional)
Naming a supervisor (optional)
For each sharing commitment by the organization, indicate if it is covered by a sharing agreement

section.title: Profile a role (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes
Assignments may change for tasks that specify a role, and thus sharing commitments as well.
Prerequisites
(as in Profile an entity)
Steps
(Optionally added to steps in Profile an entity)
Note that there is no such thing as an “actual role”, roles are all types

listitem.para: (No additional step)

section.title: Profile an agent (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes
Assignments may change for tasks that specify an agent type, and thus sharing commitments as well.
Prerequisites
(as in Profile an entity)
Steps
(Optionally added to steps in Profile an entity)

listitem.para: Declare whether or not the agent is an archetype
Declare whether the agent is a system or a person
Provide contact information as endpoints and transmission media
List security clearances

section.title: Profile a transmission medium (extends Profile an entity)
section.para: Outcomes

The applicability of a transmission medium may depend on its nature (unicast vs multicast vs broadcast) and its security classification. Changing the acceptable pattern for endpoints may render some channels invalid.
Prerequisites
(as in Profile an entity)
Steps
(Optionally added to steps in Profile an entity)

listitem.para: Declare the mode of transmission to be either unicast, multicast or broadcast
Specify acceptable endpoints as a string pattern
List other transmission media this one can delegate to
List the security level of the medium

section.title: Improving a Plan
section.para: The Improving Activities are:

listitem.para: Move tasks across segments
Generalize a task specification
Change an entity’s classification

section.title: Move tasks across segments
section.para: Outcomes
One segment is reduced in size and becomes more manageable. Goals may be added to the destination segment from moved tasks that achieve them.
Prerequisites
At least two segments are defined.
Steps

listitem.para: Remove one or more tasks from the segment of origin
Add them to the destination segment
Add, as needed, to the destination segment goals that are achieved by a moved task

section.title: Generalize a task specification
section.para: Outcomes
The number of assignments for the task grows as it matches more participating agents, and, consequently, so does the number of sharing commitments.
Prerequisites
The task is specified.
Steps
(Carry out one or more of these steps as applicable and in any order)

listitem.para: Remove the named agent from the task specification
Replace the actual agent by a type of agent
Replace the type of agent by one of the types it is tagged with
Remove the role
Replace the role by one of the roles it is tagged with
Remove the actual jurisdiction (a place)
Replace the type of jurisdiction by one of the types it is tagged with
Remove the named organization from the task specification
Replace the actual organization by a type of organization
Replace the type of organization by one of the types it is tagged with

section.title: Change an entity’s classification
section.para: Outcomes

The meaning of the entity changes. Now, different agents match the specification of tasks that reference the entity. Agents tagged with the entity get re-assigned to different tasks. As a consequence, sharing commitments also change.
Prerequisites
The entity is profiled and so are the entity types it is tagged with.
Steps

listitem.para: Add or remove tags to the entity’s profile
Or change the tags of entity types that define this entity.

chapter.title: Building and delivering Information Sharing Plans with Channels
chapter.para: Channels is a collaborative Web application for building, analyzing and deploying Information Sharing Plans.
Each Information Sharing Plan has one development version, possibly one production version, and zero or more retired versions (prior production versions).

section.title: User roles
section.para: Channels recognizes three user roles: administrators, planners and Plan participants. Administrators assign planners and participants to plans hosted by a Channels instance. Planners jointly develop, review and deploy information sharing plans. Participants view their Procedures and respond to surveys from planners about issue resolutions.
An administrator can:

listitem.para: add new plans to Channels,
assign users to plans and change their user roles,
do what any planner or participant can do, but for all Plans.

section.para: A planner can:

listitem.para: view assigned plans (all versions),
modify the development version of an assigned Plan,
view the reports from an assigned Plan (all versions),
view all Procedures from an assigned Plan (all versions),
vote with other planners to put the development version of an assigned Plan into production,
launch, access and close online surveys of selected planners and participants about issues in an assigned Plan.

section.para: A participant can:

listitem.para: view the Procedures he/she is identified with from the production version of a Plan,
access and respond to online surveys.

section.title: Logging in and accessing a Plan and segment
section.para: When accessing Channels, an unrecognized user is presented with a login screen. The user is requested to enter user name and password. To avoid being asked to login again within the current browser session, the user can check the "Remember me..." check box (the browser must allow cookies for this to work). Upon successful login, a user with Planner privileges will be taken to the Plan editor. A user without Planner privileges is taken to his/her Procedures.

section.title: Plan editor panels
section.para: The Plan editor opens on the development version of one of the Plans for which the user has planning privileges.
When the Plan Editor opens up on a Plan, Channels pre-selects a segment and a task within it. The task with its “receive” and “send” information flows are shown “collapsed” and summarized.

A planner can at any time select to see another version of the Plan, if any. A planner can also switch to another assigned Plan. Only the development version of a Plan can be modified; retired and production versions are “read-only” (all form fields are disabled, no survey can be launched).

A planner can at any time select which segment within a Plan to view or work on. The tasks and information flows of the selected segment are visualized as a flow map (a directed graph). The selected task is highlighted (by a gray rectangle) in the flow map.

The Plan editor window has four principal panels:
The Plan and Segment bar at the top
The information flow map
The panels showing the selected task at the bottom
The collaboration panel to the right

section.title: The Plan and Segment Bar
section.para: The Plan and Segment bar identifies the currently selected segment within the currently edited Plan. If applicable, drop down menus give the planner access to other versions of the Plan, to other Plans, and to others segments within the current Plan.
A "Show" menu gives access to:

listitem.para: the collaboration panel, if collapsed
the Plan panel
the Segment panel
surveys
all generated Procedures
the administration panel (if the use has Administrator privileges)
a map of all segments in the Plan
and a help window

section.para: An "Action" menu enables the planner to act on the segment as a whole by:

listitem.para: sending a message about the segment
adding or pasting a copied task
adding an "ad hoc" issue to the segment
pasting a copied attachment to the segment
moving tasks from this segment to another

section.para: Other available actions include:

listitem.para: Undoing the last action (if possible)
Redoing the last undone action (if possible)
Removing the current segment from the Plan
Logging out of Channels

section.para: The Help icon opens a Help window with this content.
The Left and righ arrow buttons are Channels' "back and forward" buttons. They are to be used instead of the browser's back and forward button which take users out of Channels.
Clicking on the name of the segment (upper left corner) opens up the "About segment" panel where the name, description and definition of the segment can be edited.

section.title: Information flow map
section.para: Tasks are the nodes (icons over text) in the graph and the information needs, capabilities and sharing flows are the arrows.

Tasks and flows are drawn in red if they have known issues. Green and red traffic lights represent the start and end of the event phase covered by the segment. Tasks that are triggered by the start of the segment are connected to the green traffic light icon. Tasks that terminate the event phase are linked to the red traffic light.

Information flows (information shared), information needs (information needed for carrying out a task) and information capabilities (shareable information produced by carrying out a task) are shown as arrows. Single-headed arrows represent notifications. Double-headed arrows are requests, with the empty arrow head pointing to the task that consumes the information request, and with the full arrow head pointing to the task that consumes the answer (the requested information flows to it).

Small squares indicate to-be-determined tasks. An arrow from a task to a dot represents an information capability of the task (information produced by the task that can be shared for use in other tasks). An arrow from a small square to a task represents an information need of the task (the task needs information possibly produced by other tasks).
When risks and goals are shown in a flow map they appear respectively as colored flags and stars connected to tasks and segment start and end icons.
Tasks within a blue rectangle denote tasks from other segments that are connected by sharing flows to tasks in the selected segment.
A flow map legend can be shown by clicking on the "help" icon in a flow map.

section.title: Task and flow panels
section.para: The task and flow panels at the bottom of the Plan editor show summaries of the selected task (there is always a task selected) together with a list of summaries of its "receives"( the task's information needs and information flows to it) and a list of its "sends" (the task's information capabilities and information flows from it). Each summary can be expanded into a form.

Each of the summaries is prefixed with a colored bullet. The color of the bullet indicates how important a task or a flow is. The color indicates the calculated impact of the task or the flow failing completely. Blue indicates a minor impact, yellow is major, orange is severe and red is extreme.

section.title: Collaboration panel
section.para: The collapsible "collaboration" panel on the right side lets a planner see who else is working on the Plan and what they have done (their activities). A planner can send messages to a planner or to all and can read received messages. The collaboration panel can be collapsed if more screen space for the flow map and task/flow forms is needed.

section.title: Display controls
section.para: The Plan editor gives the planner some control over the display of flow maps, forms used to specify tasks, flows, entities etc., and of the collaboration panel.
Flow maps can be quite large. A flow map can reduced to fit within the available space by clicking on the zoom-out icon. Clicking on the icon once more brings the flow map back to its normal size.

info.title: Plan editor with flow map that does not fit
Plan editor with flow map made to fit

section.para: A flow map can be maximized to use all of the screen space allocated to the Plan Editor by clicking on the "maximize" icon. A maximized flow map can be reduced to fit. A flow map is un-maximized either by clicking once more on the "maximize" icon or by selecting a task or a flow within the map.

A flow map, by defaut, does not display risks and gains (goals) and how they relate to tasks or the segment as a whole. To display risks and gains, the planner must click on the "goals" icon. Clicking again hides the goals.
Clicking on the summary of a task or flow will open its form. Channels automatically adapts the width of task and flow forms to ease editing. Clicking o the summary closes the form.
The planner can expand the height of the forms, at the expense of the flow map, by pressing the "expand forms" icon.

section.title: Editing tasks and flows
section.para: Clicking on a summary for a task opens up a form with which to edit the task specifications. Note that the fields of the form are disabled if someone else is currently editing the same task. The listed “sends” of the task (information shared by the task plus its information capabilities) and “receives” (information shared with the task plus its information needs) can also be edited by clicking on the summaries to open up their respective forms.
Note that, as a rule, none of the fields of a form anywhere in Channels need to be given a value. Any field can be left blank.

section.title: Editing a task
section.para: A task is specified first by naming it and then by categorizing it. It is further specified by stating where it is to be executed, by whom, in what role, for what jurisdiction, and on behalf of what organization. Any of the location, agent, jurisdiction, role, and organization (entities) that specify a task can be left unnamed so as to imply that more than one agent can be assigned to the task. The names of entities can refer to actual entities (Morritown, NJ, John Doe, ACME etc.) or to types of entities (a city, a certified technician, a corporation etc.).
The execution of a task can be set to be “as a team” to indicate that all assignees are to work together when carrying out the task. By default, assignees are each to execute the task independently.

A task is also described by how long it normally takes to complete, whether it repeats and how quickly, and whether it starts automatically with the segment (implying that the assigned agents would become aware of the onset of the event phase on their own).
The purpose of a task can be stated as terminating the event phase of the segment, mitigating one or more risks or achieve gains within the segment's scope.
Related reference and policy documents can be attached to the task either by URL or by uploading them. Finally, the task can be given a brief, informal description.
As with any Plan elements, a planner can add issues to those automatically detected about the task. Issues added by a planner can be removed by any planner.

section.title: Editing a "send" or "receive"
section.para: The information needed, produced or to be shared is named, its intent is identified and its elements are enumerated.
The mode of communication is given as either notification or by-request (push or pull).

If an information flow (information that's shared) is a notification, then it can be made a broadcast (information will be shared with all agents assigned to the target task) or a unicast (information will be shared with at least one agent assigned to the target task).

Keep in mind that an information flow that is a “send” to a task producing shared information is the same information flow that is a ”receive” to the task consuming the shared information. One is looking at one flow from its two ends.

An information flow is created by first adding an information need to a task (if necessary), then adding an information capability of the same name in another (also if necessary), and then connecting the need to the capability or vice-versa by setting the “from” or “to” field to the other task.

When specifying or determining the source or target of a flow, a planner can restrict the sources and targets to be within the same overall organization, within the same organization or within the same location. Adding a restriction on a sharing flow may filter out sharing commitments that would otherwise be implied by the flow (e.g. by dropping any sharing commitment that crosses organizational boundaries).

A communication delay is set either to zero (communication is to happen without delay) or to some finite time interval. For an information need, the delay represents the timeliness requirement for being notified or for getting a response to a request. For an information capability, the delay represents how quickly the information could be produced and communicated. For a sharing flow, the delay represents a “quality of service” commitment.

The communication channels over which the information is to flow can be set for both an information need, and for a notification information flow but only when viewed from the notified task. The same is true for a requested information flow when viewed from the task that responds to a request. Alternate communication channels are listed in order of preference.

When editing a “send” or “receive”, a planner can set whether sharing would normally trigger or terminate a task. A notification could trigger or terminate the receiving task. It could also terminate the sending task, if sending the notification concludes the task that produced the information. A request could trigger the task that produces the requested response.

Planners can attach documents to a “send” or “receive”. A document can be a reference (it documents), a mandating policy (it obligates sharing), a prohibiting policy (it prohibits sharing), a multiple policy (contains language that imposes obligations and restrictions) or it can be an image provided as an illustration (for example, a screenshot). If an information flow has a prohibiting policy attached to it then there can not be any implied sharing commitment.
An element of information can be assigned individual secrecy classifications and optional sourcing and handling instructions.

section.title: Segment scoping
section.para: Planners can edit the scope, name and description of a segment. A segment's edit form is accessed by selecting “About segment” from the top-most “Show” menu.

This opens a Details view on the selected segment. There, the can be renamed and the phase and event it references can be changed. The event can be given the minimum rating (low, medium, high or highest) at which the tasks and flows in segment apply. As with any other kind of Plan element, reference and policy documents can be attached to a segment, and "ad hoc" issues can be added.

The segment is further defined by identifying and describing a set of goals of organizations that relate to the segment's event phase. Goals can be risks to be mitigated or gains to be achieved. These goals are expected to be realized by tasks in the segment. A segment is expected to list at least one goal.

Risks can indirectly be curtailed by tasks that terminate the event phase. To be considered useful, tasks that do not curtail nor mitigate a risk or do not make gains are expected to at least provide information that is directly or indirectly needed by tasks that do.

The Goals view of a segment lets planners define the goals of organizations that are in scope. Goals can be added and removed. A goal is for an organization either to mitigate a risk or to make a gain. A goal is given a type (picked from a taxonomy of risks or gains), an importance (minor, major, severe for risks, low, medium or high for gains), the identity of the organization (either an actual organization or a type of organization), and whether the goal goes away when the event phase covered by the segment terminates.
The tasks that mitigate a given risk or achieve a goal in scope can be listed, sorted and navigated to.
The Map view locates on a Google® map all tasks in the segment that specify geo-locatable locations. The geo-mapping of elements is available throughout Channels.

section.title: Entities
section.para: A new entity (an agent, role, organization, place, event, phase or transmission medium) is automatically created when it is first referenced by name. Channels requires that all entities of a given kind be assigned unique names (John Smith, John Smith (1), John Smith (2) etc.).

Recall that the definitions of Plan elements can reference both actual entities (ACME Corporation, Peter Sanchez, Morristown NJ) and types of entities (a corporation, a certified emergency technician, a city). An entity is classified by tagging it with the names of entity types. An entity can only be tagged with entity types of its own kind (Warehouse A can be tagged as a building but not as a senior executive). Both actual entities and entity types can be edited.

An editable profile of an entity , actual or type, can be opened from wherever the entity is referenced by name, be it in the specification of a task, the definition of a segment, or in an aggregate or analytical view.

info.title: Accessing the profile of an entity from a task
Accessing the profile of an entity from the Plan index

section.para: Keep in mind that events, roles and transmission media in a Plan are always types. There is no actual event in a Plan because events are always anticipated. There is no such thing as an “actual role” because roles are always concepts. Transmission media are also always types because a Plan only cares about the class of a transmission medium.
The Details view shows the profile of an entity. All entity profiles, whether they are actual or types are composed of:

listitem.para: a unique name
a description (free text)
a classification (a list of entity types of the same kind)
document attachments

section.para: In addition, an entity profile always includes an index of all references to the entity (and matches, if the entity is a type), a list of all issues about the entity proper, and a filterable collection of all entities that releate to the entity.
Each kind of entity has additional, specific attributes that can also be set.

section.title: Profiling an organization
section.para: A planner profiling an actual organization can define its mission and set its location, contact information, and parent organization.

A planner can declare that it si an issue if a sharing commitment by the organization with another is not covered by an agreement, and that it is also an issue if there is a role assigned by the organization in the Plan for which no agent is known.

A planner can add entries to an organization's membership/employment roster, by naming for each entry an agent, a role, a jurisdiction (optional), a title and a supervisor agent (optional). Alternately, the planner can confirm memberships that are already implied by task specifications (a task specification can identify an agent in a role within a jurisdiction for an organization).

Inter-organizational sharing commitments are inferred from information flows that are sourced from tasks assignable to members of the organization. A sharing agreement may or may not exist for a sharing commitment that crosses organizational boundaries. It is an issue if an inter-organizational sharing commitment is unconfirmed as required by the organization. When viewing an organization, a planner can see the sharing commitments the organization makes with other organizations and confirm whether each commitment is covered or not by an agreement.

In the Details view of any kind of entity, references to the entity are listed in a filterable and paged index. Task assignments and sharing commitments for the organization, as well as issues about the organization, if any, are shown at the bottom of the view.

section.title: Profiling an agent
section.para: The profile attributes specific to an actual agent are: whether or not the agent is an archetype, whether it is a system or a person, its contact information (transmission media with endpoints where applicable), and its security clearances (secrecy classifications).

listitem.para: whether or not the agent is an archetype,
whether it is a system or a person,
its contact information (transmission media with endpoints where applicable),
and its security clearances (secrecy classifications)

section.para: In addition to profile attributes, the Details view of an agent lists the roles played by the agent, the agent's task assignments and sharing commitments, all references to the agent (indexed) and all issues detected or reported specifically about the agent.

section.title: Profiling a place
section.para: When profiling an actual place, a planner can identify what other place, if any, contains it. A planner can also give the place a street address, postal code and a geoname. If the geoname is ambiguous, more specific geonames are offered for selection.
When profiling a type of place, a planner can specify that for actual places to be of this type they must:

listitem.para: must be inside
the plan's locale or
the location of a planned event or
another actual or type of place
must contain
the plan's locale or
the location of a planned event or
another actual or type of place

section.title: Profiling a transmission medium
section.para: When editing a transmission medium, a planner can set the transmission mode to either unicast (one -to-one), multicast (one-to-many) or broadcast (one-to-any), unless the mode is already implied by another medium this one is tagged with (to make it a special case of it).
The address pattern is a “regular expression” that constrains the form an “address” can take for this medium. An empty pattern imposes no constraint.
A planner can identify the media, if any, this one can interface with as it carries out transmissions from sender to receiver.

Finally, a planner can describe the security of the transmission medium in terms of security classifications. Qualifying a medium as “US Gov/Top Secret” means that Top Secret information can be transmitted securely over this medium.
Keep in mind that all transmission media are types; there is no such thing in ISP as an actual transmission medium.

section.title: Defining an event
section.para: An event in ISP is always an entity type (all events in ISP are anticipated). A planner can set the location (actual or type) where the event would occur. A planner can also indicate whether or not this type event can terminate on its own, without the intervention of any agent.

section.title: Defining a phase
section.para: Planners can introduce any number of phases within the scope of a Plan. In addition to setting generic entity attributes (name, description, classification), a planner indicates whether a phase is before an event (pre-event), during an event (co-event) or after an event (post-event).

section.title: Entity network views
section.para: The Network view is available on agents, roles, and organizations. It displays a network graph depicting how the entity is connected by information flows to other entities of the same kind via sharing commitments. This analytical view allows a planner to filter commitment-generating information flows to, say, show only the ones from tasks executed by a specific role. The network graph is navigable. The list of flows can be further filtered, sorted and paged. Listed flows can also be navigated to.

section.title: Entity issues view
section.para: The Issues view collects and filters issues that are about an entity or that are related to it.
Waived issues can be included in or excluded from the sortable, page-able list of issues.

Surveys, whether ongoing, closed, or to-be-created, are accessible from each listed issue. Only planners can launch or close surveys. A survey gathers the opinions of planners and non-planners alike on how a particular issue should be remediated.

section.title: Acquiring and releasing edit locks
section.para: More than one planner can concurrently work on a Plan. "Collisions", where two planners are attempting to modify the same Plan element at once, are prevented by only allowing one planner at a time to modify any given task, flow or entity.

When a planner opens an edit form on a task etc., Channels attempts to grab an edit lock on behalf of the planner for task. If another planner already owns the lock, the form is shown to the first planner with the editable fields disabled.
A lock on a task, flow or entity owned by a planner is released when the planner collapses or closes its edit form, or logs out. An inactive planner eventually loses all acquired locks.
The name of the owner of a lock appears to other planners usually in the place of the "actions" menu. A message can be sent to the owner of a lock by clicking on his/her name.
A planner waiting for edit locks is notified when the locks are released. The planner is then instructed to refresh the editor in order to acquire the locks and enable disabled edit forms.

section.title: Viewing task assignments and sharing commitments
section.para: Recall that tasks are defined in terms of agents, roles, places, and organizations, and that these entities can be actual or types. A task specification may reference entity types or omit to identify by name an actual agent, role, jurisdiction, etc. so as to encompass more than one possible agent as executor of the task. A task thus defined could be assigned to more than one agent.
A planner can look up the list of known agents that are implicitly or explicitly assigned to the task (the task assignments).

Agents are implicitly bound by sharing commitments when they are assigned to tasks that are sources of information flows. A planner can look up the list of sharing commitments inferred by an information flow.

section.title: Assessing the impacts of failure
section.para: Planners can visualize what might happen should an agent fail completely at an assigned task or should a commitment to share information be broken. The consequences could be a number of “downstream” tasks failing leading to gains unachieved or risks unmitigated.

For the sake of analysis, it is assumed that a failure is always complete; a failed task does not produce any information that may be required by others, and a failed information flow does not transfer any information whatsoever.
A failure can cause a cascade of task failures if tasks directly or indirectly depend critically on or are triggered by information that fails to be produced or to be shared.

Not all sharing failures matter. If an information flow is not critical to a task or does not trigger it, then its failure does not propagate to other tasks. Furthermore, if the target of a flow can get the same information via another, non-failing flow, then the flow's failure does not matter. Finally, if information produced by an agent is necessarily consumed by the same agent then, clearly, failure to share is meaningless.

Failure analysis only concerns itself with the failure of useful tasks, that is, tasks that either achieve stated goals or produce information that triggers or is critical to other tasks that are themselves useful. (Useless tasks are flagged as issues.) Note that a task will terminate a risk if it causes a segment to end (or, more to the point, if it causes the event phase the segment is about to end) and if the risk is said to terminate with the segment.

A planner does “what-if”, failure analysis by selecting a task or by selecting an information flow (“send” or “receive”) and then looking at the consequences should it fail. The planner can take a pessimistic outlook and assume that all redundant information flows would also fail, no matter what.

The result of the analysis is a cascade of failures visualized as a directed graph of information flows, tasks, gains and risks. Risks that would otherwise be mitigated or terminated by failed tasks are shown as color-coded flags. Orange is for severe risks, yellow for major risks and blue for minor risks. Risks that would normally be mitigated by successful tasks are shown connected to these tasks. Risks that would be terminated, should a segment end, are shown connected to red stop lights. Each stop light is itself connected to a failed task that would normally end the segment.
Missed gains are shown as stars and are similarly color-coded by importance, with orange for high, yellow for medium and blue for low.

In addition to the visual map, a tabular list of failed, goal-oriented tasks (the failures that matter) is compiled and presented. The table is paginated and the columns (failing task, segment, impact, goal, magnitude of the loss, and organization impacted) can be sorted.

Failure analysis crosses segment boundaries. A failed task in one segment can cause tasks to fail in other segments. Tasks, flows and goals in segments other than the selected segment are put in blue boxes representing the other segments.

section.title: Actions
section.para: Planners can create and remove segments; add, cut, copy and paste tasks, needs, capabilities and flows, connect tasks with information flows, disconnect them, add an issue, remove a segment, move tasks across segments, add an intermediate to a flow etc. Relevant actions are all available from “action” menus within the context of a plan, segment, task, flow or entity.
Some actions have simple effects (adding a task, for example) but others can be more complex:

listitem.para: “disintermediate” removes a task that acts as a middleman in a flow
“intermediate” adds a middleman task to a flow,
“satisfy needs” automatically connects information needs of a task to matching but untapped information capabilities from other tasks,
"move tasks" moves one or more tasks from one segment to another, possibly also adding goals achieved by the moved tasks to the target segment.

section.para: Most actions can be undone and redone up and until some planner takes an action that would conflict with the undoing or redoing (for example, removing a task prevents undoing a change to one of its attributes).
These actions are available from the top actions menu:

listitem.para: Undoing the last action
Redoing the last undone action
Sending a message about the current segment
Pasting a copied task into the current segment
Pasting a copied attachment to the current segment
Adding a new issue to the current segment
Adding a new segment to the Plan
Removing the current segment
Moving tasks en masse from this segment to another
Logging out

section.para: These actions are available from the Plan's definition panel:

listitem.para: Undoing the last action
Redoing the last undone action
Sending a message about the Plan
Pasting a copied attachment to the Plan
Adding a new issue to the Plan

section.para: These actions are available from the segment's definition panel:

listitem.para: Undoing the last action
Redoing the last undone action
Sending a message about the segment
Pasting a copied attachment to the segment
Adding a new issue to the segment

section.para: These actions are available from the edit form of a task:

listitem.para: Undoing the last action
Redoing the last undone action
Sending a message about the task
Copying the task
Cutting the task (copy and remove), Note that the last task in a segment can not be removed.
Pasting a copied attachment to the task
Pasting (the specifications of a copied task)
Adding a new issue to the task
Adding a duplicate of this task to the segment
Satisfying all (satisfiable) information needs of the task
Disintermidiating (bypassing the task with flows where the task acts as middleman)

listitem.para: Undoing the last action
Redoing the last undone action
Sending a message about it
Copying it
Pasting a copied attachment to it
Duplicating it
Removing it entirely
Breaking it up (into need and capability)
Adding an intermediate task
Adding a new issue

listitem.para: Undoing the last action
Redoing the last undone action

Pasting a copied attachment to it

section.title: Adding and scoping a segment
section.para: When a planner creates a new segment, it is given a default name and scope. Planners can change the name and modify the segment's scope (the event, phase and goals it addresses).

info.title: Adding a segment to a plan

section.para: It is also initially populated with a single, unspecified task.

A planner would typically first name and describe the segment, set its scope by identifying an event, setting a threshold rating for the event, naming the phase of the event, and listing goals to be achieved). Then the planner would specify the lone task automatically added upon creating the segment. Then, additional tasks would be added, together with their information needs and capabilities. These tasks would be connected via information flows with other tasks in the selected segment or other segments.

There may come a point when a segment becomes too large (it has too many tasks and flows) to remain manageable. Planners will typically decide to create a new segment and to move a number of tasks, and attendant flows, from the oversized segment to the new segment. Usually, the tasks moved are those that directly or indirectly achieve a goal that will now be within the scope of the new segment. Note that if a goal achieved by a moved task is not in the scope of the destination segement, it is added to it.

section.title: Issue detection and management
section.para: Channels automatically detects more than 70 different kinds of issues. Planners can manually add issues to Plan elements, describe these issues and suggest remediations. Manually added issues can later be removed.

Issue detection and remediation can guide planners as to what to do next when building, fixing and improving a Plan. For example, a newly created segment with its lone task will immediately cause the detection of incompleteness issues. Resolving these incompleteness issues drives the planning process forward.

Some detected issues can be waived by planners if they are considered not to apply in a particular case. Note that when waiving an issue of a certain kind about a Plan element, all issues of this kind are also waived for that same element.
A planner can examine all issues detected or reported in the Plan and sort them by kind, by severity, by what they are about etc. to decide which ones to tackle next.

section.title: Connecting tasks with sharing flows
section.para: After adding a task, a planner may want to give it one or more information needs, and, for each need, name the information required and list the elements of information.

info.title: Information need with its elements of information

section.para: When a planner names an information, Channels suggests a list of already used information names that look like or mean something similar to the name being entered. This “semantic proximity”-based, auto-suggest capability leverages the WordNet lexical database and is available throughout Channels.

A planner may want to add an information capability to a task (shareable information produced by the specified task) and then connect it to a matching information need from another task in the selected segment or in another segment.

Connecting a capability with a need is done by selecting a task with a matching need from the “From” drop-down menu in the flow form (and vice-versa). Connecting a need with a capability creates a new information flow but does not remove the connected task' information need.

When a task has unsatisfied information needs (arrows to red dots), a planner may want to apply the “Satisfy needs” action. This automatically creates information flows with the other tasks in the Plan that can share the needed information.

section.para: A planner selects the item “About Plan” in the top “Show” menu to access the Plan panel where the planner can edit the name, description, planned phases, locale and attached documentation of the Plan.
The Plan panel also gives access to:

listitem.para: A list of all events referenced in the Plan, with the ability to declare certain events as "incidents" (i.e. "outside" events not expected to be caused by planned tasks)
The list of all secrecy classifications (also referenced in the Plan), with the ability to add and edit secrecy classifications,
The list of all organizations in scope, where a planner can indicate if an organization is expected to be assigned planned tasks,
A visualization and analysis of how the segments inter-relate
A searchable who's who of all participating agents
A searchable list of all issues anywhere in the Plan
A searchable list of all document attachments
An index of all named Plan elements (tasks, flows, entities etc.)
An overall evalutation of the Plan
A list of all registered users and their identification with agents in the Plan (particiaptions)
A mechanism for releasing the current development version of the Plan into production

section.para: The default Plan view is the Details view. Here, planners can change the name of a Plan, add phases and remove unreferenced phases. Planners can also add or view issues about the Plan as a whole.

In theAll events view, a planner can add events to the scope of the Plan. A planner can mark an event as an incident if it is caused “outside” of the Plan and not (always) as an outcome of a planned task. There is always at least one event defined in a Plan. Un-marking as incident an event that is not defined and is not referenced anywhere in the Plan removes it from the Plan

In theSecrecy classification view, a planner can view all defined secrecy classifications used to qualify elements of information (classification), transmission media (security) and agents (security clearances). Classifications can be re-ordered, references to a classification can be listed, unreferenced classifications can be removed and new classifications added.

In theAll organizations view, a planner can see all organizations within the scope of the Plan and add new ones, possibly with expectations that they be assigned tasks. An organization in scope that is expected to have tasks but has none raises a completeness issue.
A network view of all inter-organization sharing commitments is available.

In theAll segments view, planners can look at a map of all segments in the Plan. The segments can be grouped by phase or by event. Planners can browse all cross-segment sharing flows as well as all tasks in one segment that start or terminate another segment.
In theWho's who view, planners can search a list of all agents involved in the Plan.
In theAll issues view, planners can sort, filter and browse all issues currently detected or manually added within the Plan. Surveys on individual issues can be created or accessed from this view.
In theBibliography view, planners browse all the documents that are attached anywhere in the Plan.
In theIndex view, planners can find, filter, sort and navigate to all names elements (tasks, flows, entities, segments...).
The Evaluation view gives a summary evaluation of the Plan's fitness by counting the numbers of validity, completeness and robustness issues.

The Participations view lists all registered users and identites the agent, if any, that represerents each user. The planner can make or change this identification. A user that is not identified with a participating agent does not have information sharing procedures.

The Version view is where planners vote to move the development version of the Plan into production. A unanimous vote is required. Moving a development version into production creates a development version from a copy of the new production version. Planners can be sent messages to prompt them to vote.

section.title: Secrecy, security and clearances
section.para: Information classification, the security of communications and the clearances of agents can be important elements of information sharing planning in domains of human endeavor that require the compartmentalization of information. Planners can introduce one or more classification systems to a Plan.
Each classification system has a unique name and consists of a list of classifications (secrecy levels) ranked from highest to lowest.
Agents can be given clearances. Clearances are expressed as classifications (no more than one per classification system).
How secure a communication media type is is defined by the highest classification levels of the information it can transmit without infringing security requirements.
Elements of information shared or to be shared can each be given classification levels as well as indications of the source and special handling instructions.
Secrecy and security issues are automatically detected such as:

listitem.para: Classified information transmitted over an insufficiently secure channel
A commitment to share classified information with an agent who has insufficient clearances
Receiving classified information and then disseminating it with reduced classification

Channels interfaces with the SurveyGizmo® web service to create, launch, and retire surveys, and to collect responses.

section.title: Publishing information sharing procedures
section.para: Channels produces on demand an information sharing procedures report and individualized information sharing playbooks for the current Plan. The report is accessible to planners but not to participants.
The report organizes by segments and agents the Plan's task assignments, sharing commitments and related issues, and presents them in a single HTML document suitable for browsing and printing.
The Plan map and the information flow maps shown in the report are reduced to fit. Full-sized Plan map and flow maps can be retrieved as PNGs.
From the header of the report, a planner can narrow the focus to a single segment and/or agent. The inclusion of issues can also be turned on or off.
A participant can only access the information sharing procedures for the agent he or she represents, and only from the production version of a Plan.

section.title: Collaboration
section.para: The collaboration panel allows a planner to see who else is working on the current plan and find out what has done most recently to the Plan (activities). It also allows a planner to send messages to one or all planners, and view messages received. Each message, if sent in the context of a Plan element (task, flow, entity, segment etc.), contains a link to that element. Messaging is done within Channels but a planner may elect to send a copy of a message by email.

section.title: Help, support and feedback
section.para: A planner accesses this help document by pressing on the help button.
The feedback button appearing next to the flow map in the Plan editor is meant to provide feedback about the Plan.
The feedback button appearing with the online help is meant to provide feedback about Channels itself.

The feedback button gives access to an online community support service (provided by BetaEasy TM). The service allows the planner to request a feature, report a bug or leave a comment. The planner can also browse the input of other planners.

Each support community is implemented as a BetaEasy project. The community is identified by a BetaEasy project ID. A default support community is pre-defined for all Plans that don't identity their own support communities.

It is the responsibility of the administrator to give each planner access to the BetaEasy projects that correspond to the Plans they are assigned to.
